_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Nicholasville Water Treatment Plant is located six miles east of Nicholasville Kentucky. The plant is a conventional turbidity removal plant that utilizes chemical coagulation,flocculation,sedimentation and filtrationto remove suspended particles from the Raw River Water of the Ky. River. Our facility has had a great record on Chlorine Safety over the past five years, We have had no accidental releases in the past five years. Our prevention program consist of an on site Ground Water Protection Plan (Permit Number KPDES  KYG640081)  That shows we make a official Monthly inspection of the GWPP and an every two hour Operational inspection of the chemicals listed as operational chemicals in the GWPP .In addition to the GWPP we are part of the Jessamine County Emergency Operation Plan.  Hydrofluosilicic acid is mentioned in the Jessamine EOP but ours is 23% and not 50% and not a Regulated Toxic Substance and it is not  in our RMP. The following  Items are copied and pasted as it is written in the Jessamine County EOP:
 HAZARDOUS CHEMICAL (S):
NAME                      UNID#                 FORM     PACKAGED MAXIMUM          HEALTH HAZARD
                                                                        CONTAINER QUANTITY
Chlorine                   1017                     liquid        1 ton            8000 Ib                     *ERG 20
7782-50-5 cylinder *Poisonous; may be fatal if inhaled Contact may cause burns to skin and eyes. Contact with liquid may cause frostbite. Runoff from fire control or dilution water may cause pollution.
 PROTECTIVE ACTIONS: Alarm device to warn operators of a leak. There is only one escape route, west on Water Works Road, warn residents in nearby house and evacuate. Radio or phone the Nicholasville dispatcher, about the leak and the estimated rate of release. Other residents will be notified by local radio, television, or by sheriff or fire department personnel. Chlorine should settle down toward the river. The next closest ho

me is 1-quarter mile away from the plant. The wind generally blows east toward the river. Warn all residents on the way out Water Works Road. Nicholasville is 6 miles west of the water plant. Water plant southeast to Richmond is 7 miles. We would recommend mass evacuation depending on the severity and the quantity. Have 911 notify Madison County. There would not be necessity to have in-place sheltering due to evacuation of the public. Ref. Jessamine County EOP, Annex F for sheltering and Annex EE for evacuation procedures. Re-entry into the area will be restricted until officials deem the area safe. Only the Incident Commander will authorize re-entry. Area hospitals in Lexington possess the capability to decontaminate and treat patients exposed to the chemical. EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT ON HAND/TRAINING/EXERCISING: Two S.C.B.A. and a ton cylinder repair kit are on site. Emergency phone number 1- 800-6546 and 911 are posted. Procedures are in place for Leaks, spills and evacuation purposes for employees to study. Community: Refer to the Jessamine County Emergency Operation Plan, ERIL, for county emergency response equipment available to respond to a release at the facility. Local emergency response personnel are trained to OSHA 1910.120 awareness, operations and technician level. Jessamine County has established exercise schedule, which includes three (3) functional, and one (1) full-scale exercise every four years of which the Nicholasville Water Treatment Plant personnel are willing to take part in annual training exercises with city fire and local DES staff.  SPILL CONTAINMENT/CLEAN-UP/DISPOSAL: A release of HFS would most likely be contained to the respective storage room and would not need to be contained and collected by plant personnel. Chlorine will vaporize immediately but can be exhausted outside from its storage and usage area; however, following any chemical release, those personnel-taking place in confinement or containment would need to be decontaminated. Equ

ipment would have to be cleaned to prevent corrosion. All contaminated runoff from decontamination operations will be collected and disposed of according to a disposal plan that will be developed and coordinated with the NREPC prior to disposition. Clay Corman; Jessamine Station Pike, 885-4955 is a local private contractor and is aware of our operations and would be available to assist in containment, clean-up and disposal if it were deemed necessary.
EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION
Local 24 hr. warning number (LEPC): 911
Haz-mat Coord. (Day): 859-885-9466 or 859-885-9467 (Night): 859-885-9466 or
	859-885-9467
Alt Coord. (Day): Same As Above
	(Night): Same As Above
Nicholasville Fire Dept: 911
Nicholasville Police Department: 911
DES Coord. (Day): 859-885-9466 or 859-885-9467 (Night): 859-887-5840 or
	859-885-9467
Jessamine County Fire District Rescue: 911
Kentucky Emergency Response Commission (KERC): 502-564-7815
Kentucky DES Area Coordinator: 859-246-2334 (office) 
Nat. Resources & Envir. Port. Cabinet (NR&EPC): 502-564-3280
National Response Center (NRC): 1-800-424-8802
Envir. Prot. Agency (EPA) Hotline: 1-800-535-0202 Chemtrec: 1-800-424-9300

State Fire Marshal 1-502-564-3626
As part of planed changes, we are in the process of rebuilding the plant in the next year or two and at that point we are going to Liquid Bleach as a disinfectant in place of the Chlorine Gas.

Sincerely,
Gregory S. Hobson
Nicholasville Water Treatment Plant Superintendent
